description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: People have some pretty bad speech habits. We're here to correct that.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: A mounted arm will raise up and slap you in the face if you say too many trigger words (such as "like").

description_sections.heading: How I built it
description_sections.content: Use Google cloud's voice recognition API to detect trigger words. Communicate with an Arduino to drive the appropriate motors when a slap is needed.

description_sections.heading: Challenges I ran into
description_sections.content: We tried using a Raspberry Pi at first, but it was too slow for the voice processing, so we had to move over to doing the voice processing on a computer and then the motor controls on an Arduino.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that I'm proud of
description_sections.content: We made progress.

description_sections.heading: What I learned
description_sections.content: Raspberry Pi's don't have spectacular processing power. Testing should happen sooner in case things break.

description_sections.heading: What's next for You like jazz?
description_sections.content: Better mobility (right now it's tied down by power supplies and a computer).

description_sections.content: arduino python

winners.tagline: FlameBot is the autonomous vehicle of the future, controlled with an accelerometer and has a flamethrower.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: We really love autonomous vehicles. We also love blowing stuff up. Thus we came up with the flamebot.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: The vehicle is designed to move with respect to the motion sensor on an android phone. It also has a malfunctioning flamethrower on the back.

description_sections.heading: How I built it
description_sections.content: Much of the hardware we sourced ourselves, including all electronics and the chassis of the vehicle. However, the container for the butane canister for the flamethrower was laser cut in the invention studio. The entire structure was then mounted onto the chassis

description_sections.heading: Challenges I ran into
description_sections.content: The flamethrower was the greatest challenge we face, and as a result is incomplete. The lighting mechanism for the flame does not work as we did not have the correct parts.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that I'm proud of
description_sections.content: We are really proud of the fact that we have motion based on accelerometer readings from our android device

description_sections.heading: What I learned
description_sections.content: We learnt that electronics is what we're good at, but when it comes to manufacturing things, we are the opposite.

description_sections.heading: What's next for FlameBot
description_sections.content: Complete the flamethrower and watch the cash roll in.

description_sections.content: bluetooth mbed

winners.tagline: Combining the power of motion detection and virtual reality, we present a fully immersive game to test communication

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: All of our members, as young and curious little children, were obsessed with a single television show: Hole in the Wall. Coming into BuildGt, we all strived to recreate such extravagant childhood memories but make the experience much more interesting than merely stepping through walls. We decided to transport not only the player but also his or her friends into a world filled with camaraderie and edge-of-the-seat suspense!

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: Our programs take in user movement and simulate a human-realistic model within a 3-Dimensional world. The goal of the game is to successfully "morph" your body in order to fit into a human like cutout in a wall that's moving towards you at a constant speed. But wait, there's a twist! The person, trying to fit in the hole can't even see it! This is where the teamwork aspect plays in. Ideally, the game is played with two players: one as the eyes and the other as the body. One player uses the VR headset and is able to see the wall coming at him or her but is forced to tell the person standing in front of the Kinect to perform certain movements in order for both players to survive. If one person screws up, they both FAIL!

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content: Throughout the creative process, we used and implemented a plethora of technologies. We incorporated a Kinect sensor to accurately track the physical players movements and position within a certain field. To accommodate this, we also use the computer vision/machine learning library OpenCV in order to bring the movements to pinpoint accuracy. Following these measurements we use python, opensocket, and Raspberry Pi in order to transmit the data in real time. Once it reaches the pi, a led portrays if the data is being received or not. Once reaching here, we made the pi broadcast the data to all devices besides the sender, which is primarily the unity app running on the virtual reality device. Once here, the unity program determines the shape of the model in real-time and portrays a figure in front of the viewer. Now the viewer has visual feedback of the second player making actions in front of the Kinect device. The transmission of data occurs with the pi and provides a feedback loop between the vr and the kinect.

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: A lot. Many libraries were difficult to work with and the fact that none of us were previous game developers and were brand new to unity didn't help at all. However, we were able to adapt and learn a lot. Object collision was an absolute pain to work with and took us way too much time. Thus, our UI is not as nice as we wanted it to be and we don't have the game fully functional.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that we're proud of
description_sections.content: We are more than proud with what we were able to produce. With our lack of any prior skillset, the fact that we were able to construct something remotely close to our goal is simply mind boggling.

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: Third party libraries SUCK. But on a brighter note we learned a lot about unity and the interplay of multiple devices and data transfer. Although we didn't reach our ideal goal, we feel more than accomplished with our final product.
